title: Autonomic Neuropathy
icd10: G90.3 (Multi-system degeneration of the autonomic nervous system)
G99.0 (Autonomic neuropathy in diseases classified elsewhere)
scope: ** Evaluation and management of peripheral autonomic neuropathy in adults. Covers cardiovascular autonomic dysfunction (orthostatic hypotension, heart rate abnormalities), sudomotor dysfunction, gastrointestinal dysmotility, urogenital dysfunction, and pupillary abnormalities. Includes diabetic, autoimmune (AAG), paraneoplastic, amyloid, hereditary (HSAN/FAP), and toxic etiologies. Excludes central autonomic failure (MSA, pure autonomic failure) as primary diagnosis but includes in differential.

Referrals & Consults.item: Autonomic disorders specialist/neurologist for formal autonomic testing (tilt table, QSART, Valsalva), CASS scoring, and chronic management guidance
Cardiology consultation for cardiovascular autonomic neuropathy evaluation, arrhythmia risk assessment, and cardiac amyloidosis workup if suspected
Endocrinology for optimization of diabetic control if diabetic autonomic neuropathy; adrenal insufficiency evaluation
Gastroenterology for gastroparesis management, colonic dysmotility workup, and nutritional support if severe GI autonomic dysfunction
Urology for neurogenic bladder evaluation, urodynamic testing, and management of urinary retention or incontinence
Genetic counseling for suspected hereditary autonomic neuropathy (HSAN, FAP/hATTR) including family screening implications
Hematology/Oncology if amyloidosis confirmed (AL amyloid) or paraneoplastic antibodies positive for malignancy workup
Physical therapy for balance training, fall prevention, and exercise tolerance optimization given orthostatic limitations
Psychiatry/Psychology for management of comorbid depression, anxiety, and adjustment to chronic autonomic dysfunction

Patient Instructions.item: Rise slowly from lying to sitting to standing with 1-2 minutes at each position to allow hemodynamic adjustment and prevent falls
Drink at least 2-3 liters of fluid daily; bolus 500 mL water 15-30 minutes before prolonged standing to raise BP via osmopressor reflex
Wear waist-high compression stockings (30-40 mmHg) during all upright activity to reduce venous pooling and orthostatic symptoms
Recognize warning symptoms of OH (lightheadedness, tunnel vision, weakness) and immediately sit or lie down to prevent syncope and injury
Return to ED if syncope occurs, chest pain develops, new neurological symptoms appear, or GI/urinary symptoms acutely worsen
Avoid triggers that worsen OH: hot environments, large carbohydrate-heavy meals, alcohol, prolonged hot showers, rapid positional changes, straining
Monitor blood glucose closely if diabetic, as tight glycemic control slows progression of diabetic autonomic neuropathy
Keep a symptom diary tracking syncope/presyncope episodes, GI symptoms, and urinary symptoms to guide treatment adjustments

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Strict glycemic control (HbA1c <7%) if diabetic to slow or prevent progression of autonomic neuropathy
Eat small, frequent meals rather than large meals to reduce postprandial hypotension from splanchnic blood pooling
Avoid alcohol which causes vasodilation and worsens orthostatic hypotension
Review all medications with prescriber to identify and discontinue drugs that worsen OH: diuretics, vasodilators, alpha-blockers, tricyclics, opioids
Maintain consistent sleep schedule; sleep with head of bed elevated 6-10 inches to reduce nocturnal natriuresis and supine hypertension
Counter-pressure maneuvers (leg crossing, muscle tensing, squatting) at onset of prodromal symptoms to abort presyncope episodes
Home safety evaluation to remove fall hazards given increased syncope risk from neurogenic OH

differential.features: Central autonomic failure; cerebellar ataxia (MSA-C) or parkinsonism (MSA-P); hot cross bun sign on MRI; progressive
differential.tests: MRI brain (hot cross bun sign, putaminal changes); cardiac MIBG (preserved in MSA vs reduced in Lewy body)

differential.features: Isolated peripheral autonomic failure without somatic neuropathy; no motor/sensory deficits; slowly progressive
differential.tests: Autonomic testing; NCS normal; plasma NE very low supine and standing; skin biopsy may show alpha-synuclein

differential.features: HR rise ≥30 bpm without OH; predominantly younger females; no BP drop meeting OH criteria
differential.tests: Active stand test: HR rises ≥30 bpm without SBP drop ≥20 mmHg

differential.features: Parkinsonism precedes or accompanies autonomic symptoms; asymmetric tremor, rigidity, bradykinesia
differential.tests: DaTscan; clinical exam for parkinsonism; cardiac MIBG (reduced in PD)

differential.features: Orthostatic hypotension with hyperkalemia, hyponatremia, hyperpigmentation, fatigue, weight loss
differential.tests: AM cortisol; ACTH stimulation test; ACTH level

differential.features: Temporal relationship to medication; common offenders: antihypertensives, antidepressants, alpha-blockers, diuretics
differential.tests: Medication reconciliation; improvement with dose reduction/discontinuation

differential.features: OH and tachycardia resolving with volume repletion; identifiable cause (GI illness, poor intake)
differential.tests: Labs showing hemoconcentration; resolution with IV fluids

differential.features: Autonomic neuropathy with cardiomyopathy, nephropathy, hepatomegaly; peripheral neuropathy; macroglossia
differential.tests: SPEP/UPEP; free light chains; TTR gene testing; tissue biopsy with Congo red

differential.features: Autonomic neuropathy with sicca symptoms (dry eyes, dry mouth); small fiber predominant
differential.tests: SSA/SSB antibodies; Schirmer test; lip biopsy; ANA

differential.features: Subacute onset; often with other paraneoplastic features; anti-Hu, anti-CRMP5 positive
differential.tests: Paraneoplastic antibody panel; CT/PET for occult malignancy

differential.features: Most common cause; concurrent length-dependent sensorimotor neuropathy; long-standing or poorly controlled diabetes
differential.tests: HbA1c; NCS/EMG showing distal sensorimotor neuropathy; autonomic testing

All newly diagnosed: within 2-4 weeks for formal autonomic testing; established patients: q3-6 months; post-medication changes: 2-4 weeks
Diabetic patients: endocrinology q3 months for glycemic optimization; GI follow-up for gastroparesis management; urology for bladder dysfunction
